title: James' Case: Functional Limitation Due to Hodgkin's Lymphoma and Associated Myalgia
clinical_history: James is a 34-year-old male marketing executive who presented to his primary care physician three months ago with persistent, painless swelling of the left side of his neck and intermittent low-grade fever. Over the ensuing six weeks, he developed increasing fatigue, night sweats, and unexplained weight loss (~6 kg). Approximately four weeks ago, he began to experience a deep, achy pain in his left upper trapezius and surrounding cervical musculature, which worsened after physical exertion or carrying light loads. Additionally, he reports mild aching and stiffness in his proximal humerus on the left. He finds it difficult to engage in his regular fitness routine due to fatigue and muscle soreness, and he occasionally feels tingling sensations radiating to his left arm, especially with overhead activities. Excisional biopsy confirmed classical Hodgkin's lymphoma (nodular sclerosis type), stage II. Chemotherapy (ABVD regimen) commenced three weeks ago.

nprs.affected_area: left cervical and upper trapezius muscle group (deep ache, persistent)
left proximal humerus and deltoid region (intermittent, mild ache and stiffness)

aggrevating_factors: Physical exertion (lifting groceries, prolonged sitting at workstation), carrying moderate loads on left shoulder, prolonged neck flexion or rotation, and emotional stress.
picture: [insert image showing swelling over left supraclavicular fossa and area of reported muscle discomfort, with regions of pain on the cervical and upper trapezius marked].
easing_factors: Resting in supine, use of a soft pillow to support cervical spine, gentle self-massage, and short-acting acetaminophen.
past_history: Non-contributory; no prior musculoskeletal or systemic illnesses.
medical_history: Non-smoker, no relevant drug allergies. Father had ischemic heart disease.
medications: Chemotherapy (ABVD regimen: doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, dacarbazine); acetaminophen as needed for pain; ondansetron for chemotherapy-induced nausea.
personal_history: Lives alone, independent in activities of daily living but recently struggling with work productivity due to fatigue and malaise. Previously highly active (running & recreational basketball). Expresses significant anxiety regarding diagnosis and impacts on career and social life.
imaging: CT scan of neck/chest/abdomen showed multiple enlarged cervical and supraclavicular lymph nodes on the left, no bony involvement; MRI neurography negative for nerve infiltration.
